Trump ’ s White House is now taking the Statue of Liberty
The surest sign of regime change is when they begin to attack the statues .
Americans appreciate it , as do any others - hence the carefully staged overthrow of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad ’ s Firdo Square in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , surely knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe to the Statue of Liberty in a heated dispute with CNN ’ s Jim Acosta about the president ’ s proposals to slash legal immigration .
To be fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A horde of boat owners and liberty imitators would have hated him if he had .
But it took on its importance , and in particular the importance attributed to it when Emma Lazarus 's famous poem was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
As Miller called Acosta , " I don 't want to go into a whole thing about history here , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that illuminates the world .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . '
Miller is factually correct , but as he put it himself , this is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary response to Lazarus 's shouting words , the only one in which a state invites not just any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : " Your mosquitoes , your poor , / your crowded masses who long to breathe freely / the miserable waste of your rich coasts . "
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' on our screens was better visible .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict , because of the importance of a statue , is part of a broader political and cultural dispute : it is indeed a conflict about America ’ s importance .
Lazarus - and her friends who tried to place their words at the base after their death - knew very well that they did a highly political act .
The sculpture was intended to show the links between French and American republicanism by portraying the female embodiment of freedom in a time-worn classic visual representation .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of the exiles .
The combination of poetry with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , the right wing people wanted to change it a long time ago .

The great scream of Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty was not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative , bringing the American flame into the world that is being reinterpreted : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It should carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch should not clear the way to the United States . '
Quite unusual here is Limbaugh .
The meaning of the statue is entirely a question of the position of perception .
Lazarus 's great imaginative act was to see them as they were seen by the exhausted , wretched but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
It is literally a question of seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome they must hear .
And that , of course , is not the perspective that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not intended to enlighten the way , but to inflame the hatred that is their only source of power .

Poverty and Death in Indonesia ’ s Goldland
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It even rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of Paniai rule in the restless Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour the charred bulb is removed and swallowed with zealous , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the mud floor - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , for example , washing clothes with muddy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband 's four wives , she was not given any fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , it can be dangerous to work late : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around the village after 5 p.m. ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony that was admitted in 1969 after a disputed referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were supposed to vote in front of the occupying forces by means of a public show of hands . in , , , and . , , , , , , , ,

An existing movement that campaigned for independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which controls the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers from it .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea comprising the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is desert .
There is no public transport .
The town , with a population of around 19,000 , consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated iron roofs converted by rust into different yellow-brown tones .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and practically no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans revered a god named Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei , pointing to her lively hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
'We used to have only sheets on our bodies . '
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of Asia ’ s worst child mortality and literacy rates .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s Goldland .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the freeport McMoran of Phoenix , is located just 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport has mined gold and copper worth $ 3.1 billion .
Papua also has an estimated $ 78 billion of wood resources .
These riches , however , are a source of misery for the Papua , ensuring that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a suffocating presence .

A 2005 investigation in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid almost $ 20 million to local military personnel and units between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten this golden goose and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua tribal highlands in the 1970 ’ s became genocide according to the Asian Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

'We Will Lose All ' is stated in a 2016 report by the Brisbane Archdiocese containing reports of last year 's atrocities , such as unlawful executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal repression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims as incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have intensified as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but the demographic trend is changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanese war canteens sell roasted chicken and Gado-Gado , a mixed vegetables with peanut sauce served .
Local people struggle to stay here .

Migrants have begun to sell chickens and vegetables more cheaply on the traditional market than the local Papua ,  explains Abeth You , a 24-year-old Paniai native who moved to the provincial capital of Jayapura .
'It cost Papua 's native Papua - the Mama Mama [ the women ] of Papua - their market ' .
Indonesian President Joko Widodo , commonly known as Jokowi , promised during his 2014 campaign to address the inequalities and violations of rights in Papua .
The former carpenter secured 27 of the total 29 districts of Papua - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today the locals feel betrayed .
Our hearts are broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , expecting him to fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says You .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration , Paniai suffered a low point in October .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children was out and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the darkness on a motorcycle .
The starved children told them that they should turn on their headlights .
One of the soldiers took offence at their tone and later returned with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavet Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their rifles , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was so severely beaten that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was burned , and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered at a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military command center to demand justice .
They carried ceremonial hunting arches and performed the Waita dance - in the circle , imitating a bird song - by Papuas Mee Pago tribe .
Some protesters began throwing stones at police and military posts .

When the mood was heated , a command was sent to the soldiers over an internal radio : " If the masses resist more than three times , they shoot them dead , " says an official TIME document that was not released to the local media .
